facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 340 of 1957 filed in Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 340 of 1957.

facts.text: Appeal from judgment and order dated November 29, 1954, of Hyderabad High Court in Reference No. 234/5 of 1953-54.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal from the judgment and order dated November 29, 1954, of the Hyderabad High Court in Reference No. 234/5 of 1953-54.

facts.text: Assessee is a registered firm consisting of five brothers and the wife of a deceased brother with equal shares.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee is a registered firm companysisting of five brothers and the wife of a deceased brother having equal shares in the profit and loss of the partnership.

facts.text: Firm appointed sole selling agents and sole distributors for Hyderabad State for cigarettes by Vazir Sultan Tobacco Co., Ltd. under Board resolution dated January 6, 1931.

anchor.surface_text: The firm was appointed the sole selling agents and sole distributors for the Hyderabad State for the cigarettes manufactured by M s. Vazir Sultan Tobacco Co., Ltd., under the terms of a -resolution of the Board of Directors dated January 6, 1931.

facts.text: Arrangement allowed discount of 2% on gross selling price for distributorship within Nizam's Dominions.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Baker reported that an arrangement had been, companye to for the time being whereby the firm of Vazir Sultan Sons, were given the distributorship of Charminar Cigarettes within the H. E. H. the Nizams Dominions and that they were allowed a discount of 2 on the gross selling price.

facts.text: No written agreement or correspondence exchanged for 1931 arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: No written agreement was entered into between the Company and the assessee in respect of the above mentioned arrangement number was there any companyrespondence exchanged between them in this behalf.

facts.text: In 1939, arrangement expanded to discount of 2% on all goods sold in and outside Hyderabad State.

anchor.surface_text: In 1939 another arrangement was arrived at between the assessee and the companypany whereby the assessee was given a discount of 2 number only on the goods sold in the Hyderabad State but on all the goods sold in the Hyderabad State and outside Hyderabad State.

facts.text: No Board resolution or written agreement for 1939 arrangement.

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear that the Board of Directors passed any resolution in support of this new arrangement number was any agreement drawn up between the parties incorporating the said new ar- rangement.

facts.text: On June 16, 1950, Board passed resolution reverting to 1931 arrangement effective from June 1, 1950, paying O.S. Rs. 2,26,263 compensation to Vazir Sultan Sons.

anchor.surface_text: On June 16, 1950, the Board of Directors passed the following resolution reverting to the old arrangement embodied in the resolution dated January 6,1931- The Chairman, having referred to resolution No. 24 passed at the board meeting held on 6-1-31 and having reported that Vazir Sultan Sons had agreed to revert to the arrangement outlined in that resolution with effect from 1-6-50, it was on the proposition of Mr. S. N. Bilgrami, seconded by Mr. N. Chenoy resolved that payment of the sum of O. S. Rs. 2,26,263 be made to Vazir Sultan Sons by way of companypensa- tion,

facts.text: Out of compensation, Rs. 6,920 paid by Vazir Sultan Sons to D.B. Akki Co. as compensation.

anchor.surface_text: Vazir Sultan Sons, to pay D. B. Akki Co., out of that amount the sum of O. S. Rs. 6,920 also by way of companypensation.

facts.text: Assessee received Rs. 2,19,343 in year of account 1359 F relevant to assessment year 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The sum of Rs. 2,19,343 was accordingly received by the assessee in the year of account 1359 F.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer included Rs. 2,19,343 in assessee's total income as revenue receipt for 1951-52.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer included this sum in the assessees total income and taxed it as a revenue receipt.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 2,19,343 as capital receipt, compensation for loss of agency, not taxable.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner held that the sum of Rs. 2,19,343 was number a revenue receipt but a capital receipt being companypensation for the loss of the agency and as such number liable to tax.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer C Ward Hyderabad appealed to Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, which held sum as revenue receipt liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer  C Ward  Hyderabad thereupon preferred an appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, which held that the said sum received by the assessee was a revenue receipt and liable to tax.

facts.text: Tribunal referred question to High Court under sec. 66(1) of Income-tax Act: Whether Rs. 2,19,343 is revenue or capital receipt.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee then applied to the Appellate Tribunal for a reference to the High Court under sec. 66 1  of the Income-tax Act and the Tribunal accordingly referred the following question of law to the High Court- Whether the sum of O. S. Rs. 2,19,343 received by the assessee Firm from Vazir Sultan Tobacco Co., Ltd., is a revenue receipt or a capital receipt ?

facts.text: Hyderabad High Court answered in favour of assessee, holding sum not liable to tax.

anchor.surface_text: The High Court answered the question in favour of the assessee stating the question in a different form, viz., Whether the sum of O. S. Rs. 2,19,343 received by the assessee firm from Vazir Sultan Tobacco Co., Ltd., is liable to be taxed under the Indian Incometax Act?

facts.text: High Court granted certificate of fitness on February 21, 1955.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant thereafter applied to the High Court for a certificate of fitness which was granted by the High Court on February 21, 1955, and hence this appeal.

facts.text: Mr. Mohd. Sultan and Mr. Hameed Sultan did not take part in June 16, 1950 resolution as partners but accepted terms on behalf of firm.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. Mohd. Sultan Mr. Hameed Sultan stated that, as partners in the firm of Vazir Sultan Sons, they did number take part in this resolution, although they had accepted on behalf of Vazir Sultan Sons, the terms thereof.

facts.text: Supreme Court judgment delivered March 20, 1959 by Bhagwati J. (majority), Kapur J. separate judgment.

anchor.surface_text: 1959. March 20. The Judgment of Bhagwati and Sinha, JJ., was delivered by Bbagwati, J. Kapur, J., delivered a separate Judgment.

facts.text: Bhagwati J. held sum of Rs. 2,19,343 is capital receipt, appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: The result, therefore, is that the appeal fails and will stand dismissed with companyts throughout.

facts.text: Kapur J. dissented, held sum is revenue receipt, would allow appeal.

anchor.surface_text: I would therefore allow this appeal with companyts throughout.

facts.text: Agency terminable at will of the company, no enforceable agreement for fixed term.

anchor.surface_text: The agency agreement was terminable at the will of the Company and if the Company chose to do so the assessee had numberremedy at law in regard to the same.

facts.text: Assessee's business income from cigarette distribution and acid factory in Hyderabad State was Rs. 4,53,159 in accounting year.

anchor.surface_text: During the accounting year the amount of income, profits and gains of the assessees from the cigarette distribution business and from another source, i. e., Acid Factory within the State of Hyderabad was Rs. 4,53,159.

facts.text: No finding on how much income attributable to cigarette business vs acid factory.

anchor.surface_text: The order of the Income-tax Officer or the Appellate Tribunal does number show bow much of this sum was attributable to the Cigarette distribution business and how much to the other source.

facts.text: Profit from Hyderabad State agency alone exceeded compensation received for outside agency termination.

anchor.surface_text: The amount of profit which the assessee made from working the agency companytract in Hyderabad State alone was much more than the amount which the assees received for the termination of the whole of their agency outside the State.

holdings.text: The sum of Rs. 2,19,343 received by the assessee from the Company was a capital receipt

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Assistant Commissioner as well as the High Court were thus justified in the conclusion to which they came, viz., that the sum of Rs. 2,19,343 received by the assessee from the Company was a capital receipt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Agency formed fixed capital and profit-making apparatus; termination sterilised it pro tanto; applies precedents like Shaw Wallace, Van den Berghs, Glenboig

holdings.text: The agency agreements constituted a capital asset of the assessee's business, part of its fixed capital and profit-making apparatus

anchor.surface_text: The agency agreements in fact formed a capital asset of the assessees business worked or exploited by the assessee by entering into contracts for the sale of the charminar cigarettes manufactured by the Company to the various customers and dealers in the respective territories. This asset really formed part of the fixed capital of the assessees business

holdings.reasoning_summary: Assessee not in business of agencies; agency enabled distribution business, not stock-in-trade; distinguishes ordinary trading contracts

holdings.text: Compensation for termination of agency outside Hyderabad State is capital receipt as sterilisation pro tanto of capital asset

anchor.surface_text: It was the price paid for sterilising the asset from which otherwise profit might have been obtained. What is true of the whole must be equally true of part.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies Glenboig principle to partial termination; even one agency agreement's termination destroys profit-making apparatus pro tanto

holdings.text: Periodicity or expected regularity not essential ingredient of income under business head

holdings.reasoning_summary: Qualifies Shaw Wallace definition; later cases like Kamakshya Narain, Raghuvanshi Mills show income need not be periodical under business; irrelevant here

holdings.text: Character of receipt determined from recipient's point of view; terminability at will immaterial if capital asset
